name: Central African Republic
currentCrisisSummary:
The Central African Republic (CAR) endures **protracted state collapse**, driven by decades of **foreign interference**, a **predatory state structure inherited from colonialism**, and the **systematic extraction of its natural resources**. The central government's authority is negligible, with much of the country controlled by armed groups and foreign mercenaries.

This power vacuum is the direct legacy of a **neo-colonial model** where external powers (historically France, now Russia) cultivate clients to secure access to diamonds, gold, and uranium. The current phase involves reliance on Russian private military contractors (Africa Corps/Wagner) who provide regime security for **lucrative mining concessions**. This **mercenary-driven resource extraction** perpetuates violence, displaces civilians, and siphons wealth offshore, inflicting extreme humanitarian distress upon the population.

colonialRoot.legacy:
French colonial rule in Ubangi-Shari was exceptionally brutal and extractive. The territory was carved up and leased to private concessionary companies, which were granted total power to exploit rubber, ivory, and diamonds using a system of forced labour. This model established the state not as a provider of public goods, but as an instrument of violent resource extraction for foreign enrichment.

This foundational structure was never dismantled. At independence, France handed power to a compliant elite who perpetuated the predatory system. The legacy is a chronically weak state, devoid of legitimacy and institutional capacity, where control over resources remains the primary motive for political power and the ultimate driver of conflict.

historicalContext.title: Post-Colonial French Intervention
historicalContext.description: For decades after 'independence' in 1960, CAR remained a key outpost of 'FranÃ§afrique'â€”a system of neo-colonial control. France repeatedly intervened militarily to install, protect, and depose client rulers (such as Jean-BÃ©del Bokassa) to safeguard its strategic and economic interests, including access to uranium. This persistent interference prevented the development of genuine sovereignty and entrenched a political culture of dependency on an external patron.

historicalContext.title: Debt And Structural Adjustment
historicalContext.description: Following decades of misrule and instability, CAR became heavily indebted and fell under the control of the IMF and World Bank. The Structural Adjustment Programmes imposed in the 1990s mandated the privatisation of state enterprises and severe austerity, dismantling what little public service capacity existed. This neoliberal shock therapy further weakened the state, deepened poverty, and entrenched a reliance on foreign aid, creating a perfect vacuum for armed groups to flourish and for the cycle of conflict to intensify.

historicalContext.title: Resource Curse and Predatory Elites
historicalContext.description: CAR's immense mineral wealth has been a curse, fuelling conflict and enriching a small domestic elite and their foreign partners while the population remains impoverished. The diamond trade, in particular, is deeply linked to illicit arms trafficking and the financing of armed groups. The state's function has been reduced to managing the contracts and security for foreign extractive industries, creating a permanent incentive for rival factions to seize power through violence to gain control of these revenue streams.

historicalContext.title: Proxy Battleground and Mercenary Economy
historicalContext.description: In recent years, CAR has become a key theatre for geopolitical competition between a declining French influence and a resurgent Russia. The government's turn to the Wagner Group (now Africa Corps) represents a shift from one imperial patron to another. This new model trades sovereign mineral rights directly for mercenary services, bypassing even the pretence of state-building. It has created a parallel economy of violence and extraction, where Russian mercenaries and their corporate affiliates operate with impunity, committing widespread human rights abuses in their campaign to secure mines and territory.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Despite the presence of a UN peacekeeping mission (MINUSCA), whose tenure has been repeatedly marred by widespread allegations of sexual exploitation and abuse by its troops, and the establishment of a Special Criminal Court (SCC) to try war crimes, accountability remains elusive. The ICC has also opened investigations. However, these legal mechanisms are critically under-resourced, politically constrained, and unable to address the actions of the most powerful actors, particularly foreign mercenaries who enjoy de facto immunity. Justice is further undermined by the selective focus on local armed groups while the foreign corporations and state actors who profit from the illicit resource trade face little to no scrutiny.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Thousands killed since 2013 by atrocities committed by all parties in the **conflict over resources and state control.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Approximately 2.8 million people (nearly half the population) require aid to survive the **consequences of state collapse and unending war.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 2 million face acute hunger, with chronic malnutrition stunting children, driven by **conflict-induced displacement and the destruction of livelihoods.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 500,000 internally displaced, forcibly uprooted by **violence linked to resource grabs and political instability.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: More than 750,000 refugees forced into neighbouring countries by the **persistent violence and lack of protection.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Less than half of medical facilities function amidst near-total healthcare collapse, a direct result of **state failure and decades of underinvestment.** Life expectancy is among the world's lowest.

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions lack safe water and basic sanitation due to the **disintegration of public infrastructure caused by chronic conflict and state neglect.**

timeline.event: **French Conquest**: In the imperial 'Scramble for Africa', and competing directly with King Leopold's brutal Congo Free State, France conquers the territory. It is named Ubangi-Shari and its colonisation is driven by the pursuit of ivory and the potential for rubber, establishing the legal and military basis for a system of pure extraction.
**Red Rubber Regime**: French concessionary companies impose a reign of terror, using forced labour and extreme violence to extract rubber, resulting in a massive depopulation of the territory.
**Nominal Independence**: France grants independence but maintains deep military, political, and economic control through the 'FranÃ§afrique' system.

**Bokassa's Empire**: Jean-BÃ©del Bokassa, initially backed by France, rules as a brutal dictator and later self-proclaimed emperor. He is ultimately removed by a French military operation when his utility wanes.

**Decade of Decay**: The state, crippled by debt, is forced to implement IMF-led Structural Adjustment Programmes. The resulting austerity triggers army mutinies and deepens the state's collapse, setting the stage for the civil wars of the 21st century.

**SÃ©lÃ©ka Coup**: The SÃ©lÃ©ka, a predominantly Muslim coalition of rebel groups from the marginalised north, captures the capital, Bangui. The coup triggers the formation of 'anti-balaka' militias, plunging the country into widespread sectarian violence.

**OpÃ©ration Sangaris**: France intervenes militarily, followed by the deployment of a UN peacekeeping force (MINUSCA). The intervention contains the worst of the violence but fails to address the root causes of the conflict.

**Enter Wagner**: The CAR government, seeking to break its dependency on the West, invites the Russian private military company Wagner Group to provide security and training in exchange for untaxed mining concessions.

**Mercenary State**: Wagner forces become integral to the regime's survival, fighting rebels and securing key mining sites. Widespread, credible reports document their involvement in massacres, torture, and looting, solidifying a new neo-colonial model of resource-for-security.

donate.description: UNHCR provides critical protection and assistance to refugees and internally displaced people, delivering shelter, aid, and support to those forced to flee the violence in CAR.
Provides safe spaces, education, and psychosocial support to children affected by the armed conflict, helping them recover from trauma.

advocacy: Demand sanctions on foreign corporations and individuals, including those affiliated with the Africa Corps/Wagner Group, involved in the illicit trade of CAR's 'blood diamonds' and gold.
Oppose all forms of foreign military interference, whether through official state armies or private mercenary companies, that serves to extract resources and prop up illegitimate regimes.
Call for the unconditional cancellation of CAR's external debt, which serves to perpetuate dependency and divert state funds away from essential services.
Support and amplify the voices of Central African civil society organisations working on peacebuilding, human rights, and good governance.
Advocate for strengthening the Special Criminal Court and other justice mechanisms with the resources and political independence to prosecute all perpetrators of war crimes, including foreign actors.
